metadata.title: Visual Detection of Cesium Ions in Domestic Water Supply or Seawater using a Nano-optode

sections.text:

Although radioscopes and gamma ray cameras have been developing to visualize radioactive species or contamination, it is not necessarily a simple matter to locate sources of contamination under high levels of background radiation. However, supramolecular approaches for environmental sensing of analyses are useful in the design of high-resolution molecular sensors. Here, we have developed an optical imaging technique for cesium ions involving an optode system in environmental water. An optode membrane was prepared incorporating a calix[6]arene derivative, which showed excellent selectivity toward cesium ions in aqueous solutions, even in water supplied for domestic use or seawater. Furthermore, this membrane was fabricated using nanoparticles with a diameter of ca. 100 nm. The nano-optode also gave an excellent response to cesium ions. Therefore, this optode provides a higher spatial resolution than existing radioscopes and gamma ray cameras under high level radioactive environments.
1. Introduction
Methods for monitoring, detecting, and removing invisible environmental hazards has received attention in recent years for safe and healthy surroundings.110 In particular, radioactive contamination has a profound and a long-term effect on the environment. Radioactive Cs 137 represents a serious environ-
mental problem in Japan following the release of large amounts of radioactive materials from the Fukushima-Daiichi nuclear power plant during an incident caused indirectly by the Great East Japan Earthquake in 2011.1113 The half-life of Cs 137 is 30.1-years so that it can be considered a long-lasting environmental pollutant in local ground soils and seawater. Currently, the only effective means for removal of radiocesium from a contaminated area is the large scale excavation of surface soil, which has been accomplished over large swathes of land in the vicinity of Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant. Decontamination projects for soil purification are proceeding with difficulties due to the strong adsorption capacity of local soil clays.14,15 In addition, the government of Japan ought to develop a regime for processing and decommissioning of nuclear power plants where necessary, including a long term plan to manage radioactive waste. These matters require the safe and effective sensing of radioactive materials where they are present as contaminating agents.
The characteristic gamma rays emitted by radioactive isotopes enable detection of several isotopes, although it is difficult to visualize these emissions over small regions and under conditions of a high radioactive background. It would be useful, therefore, if the location of cesium (or radiocesium) could be visualized in order to trace leaks or other processes from facilities containing high level radioactive materials, and to reduce the volume of radioactively contaminated materials generated in decommissioning of a nuclear reactor.16,17 With this in mind, supramolecular approaches1822 for environmental sensing might lead to resolutions higher than micrometer level. A chemical optical probe provides a higher spatial resolution
678 | Bull. Chem. Soc. Jpn. 2017, 90, 678–683 | doi:10.1246/bcsj.20170046 © 2017 The Chemical Society of Japan
and would be less expensive than existing radioscopes and gamma ray cameras.2326 We have developed a fluorescence probe with excellent selectivity for cesium ions, called “Cesium Green”,23 and successfully demonstrated the visualization of cesium ions in the freeze-dried cells of Arabidopsis.24 However, despite its excellent selectivity, Cesium Green shows no recognition toward cesium ions in water or other polar media because of the poor coupling ability.
Here we report a sensing technique for cesium ions using an optode (optical electrode), a well-known optical sensor device,27,28 based on ion exchange, which is potentially applicable not only in aqueous buffer solutions but also in water samples collected from different environments. Optodes are essentially polymer-based membranes consisting of an ionophore for the target species and a pH-responsive dye for colorimetric ion detection.29,30 In principle, target ions are trapped by the ionophore within the polymer matrix leading to simultaneous release of a proton from the pH-responsive dye to the medium to maintain charge neutrality. As a consequence, recognition events involving the ionophore and analyte ions are vizualized by color changes of the pH-responsive dye. A fiber optical sensor prepared by attaching the optode to the tip of an optical fiber probe,28 to improve spatial resolution, can be used to carry out analyses over relatively small areas, for instance on living cells.
A few examples of cesium ion selective optode membranes based on crown ether derivatives operating in buffer solutions have been reported.31 In this work, a calixarene derivative, which has been reported for its use in highly cesium ion selective electrodes,3234 was used as an ionophore in the presence of sodium and potassium ions, added to simulate seawater. First, an optode film of the calixarene in a polymer matrix was prepared, and its sensing performance for cesium ions was characterized at the naked-eye level in aqueous buffer solutions or under typical conditions for analysis, i.e., in domestic water supply and sea water samples. Furthermore, optodes prepared using nanoparticles might be applied for microscopic visualization.35 A sodium ion selective nano-optode has been reported, and was successfully applied for biological imaging in mice.36 This study has inspired us to prepare a nanoparticle optode with a diameter of ca. 100 nm, which was prepared by sonication of the membrane in a buffer solution. The nanooptode exhibits an excellent response to cesium ions. The nanooptode probe could offer resolutions greater than micrometer level in biological systems.
2. Experimental
2.1 Materials. Host molecule calix[6]arene hexaester3234 and dyestuff KD-M1337 were synthesized as described previously. Polyvinyl chloride was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Milwaukee, WI). Cationic exchanger sodium tetrakis[3,5bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]borate (TFPB) and Bis(2-hydroxyethyl)iminotris(hydroxymethyl)methane (Bis-tris) were purchased from Dojindo (Kumamoto, Japan). Bis(2-ethylhexyl) sebacate (DOS) was purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Co. (Osaka, Japan). Solvents and reagents were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co. Ltd. (Tokyo, Japan) or Wako Pure Chemical Co. (Osaka, Japan) and were used without further purification. Water used for preparation of aqueous solu-
tions was distilled using an Autostill WG220 (Yamato) and deionized using a Milli-Q Lab (Millipore). A standard OHP (Overhead Projector) slide composed of polyethylene terephthalate was used to support the optode membrane.
2.2 Measurement. UV/vis absorption spectra were measured using a Shimadzu model UV-3600 UVVISNIR. Size distribution was measured using a NICOMP 380ZLS (Particle Sizing System Co.). Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) was performed using a JEOL JSM7600-F.
2.3 Preparation of Optode Membrane. Cationic exchanger TFPB (3.0mg, 3.4¯mol), cation host molecule calix[6]arene hexaester (3.9mg, 3.4¯mol), DOS (40¯L), polyvinyl chloride (20mg), and dyestuff KD-M13 (1.8mg, 3.4¯mol) were dissolved in THF. The solution was coated onto a transparent OHP sheet with a magnetic stirrer. The film was dried for 1 hour in the dark.
2.4 Characterization ofOptode Membrane. The resulting film (Section 2.3) was cut into 1 cm © 2 cm segments to fit into a 1-cm path length plastic cuvette. MCl (M = Na+, K+, Cs+) or MCl2 (M = Ca2+, Mg2+) buffer solution (Bis-tris, pH 7.0) was added to the cuvette, then UV/vis absorption spectra were measured to characterize the response of the optode membrane toward the cations present. In addition, a spectrum in aqueous 1M NaOH solution was also taken following each measurement. This was used as a measure of the membrane at full extent of response (¡ = 1). Seawater medium was simulated using Daigo’s Artificial Seawater SP for Marine Microalgae Medium (Wako Pure Chemical Co.).
2.5 Preparation of a Nano-Optode Suspension. A portion of the THF solution (100¯L) used above (Section 2.3) to make the optode membrane was dropped onto a glass plate. The film was first dried under ambient pressure and then under reduced pressure. The resulting film was placed in Tween 20 buffer solution (15mL, 0.01wt% Bis-tris, pH 6.0). The solution was sonicated with a probe-tip sonicator. Sonication was applied until the concentration of nano-probes was optimized according to monitoring of absorption of the pH-responsive dye in the solution. The residual polymer was removed by centrifuge.36
2.6 Characterization of a Nano-Optode Suspension. The nano-optode suspension prepared in Section 2.5 was added to CsCl buffer solution (Bis-tris, pH 6.0), and the concentration of Cs+ was adjusted to selected values. UV/vis absorption spectra of the resulting solutions were measured.
3. Results and Discussion
3.1 Cesium Detection Using a Cs+-Selective Optode Membrane of Calix[6]arene Hexaester. An optode membrane responsive toward Cs+ was prepared by using a calix[6]arene hexaester derivative (Figure 1), which has already been reported as an ionophore in Cs+-selective electrode.3234 Responses of the resulting optode membrane to Cs+ and several other cations were characterized using UV/vis absorption spectroscopy in Bis-tris buffer solution (pH 7.0). Absorption spectral peaks of the pH-responsive dyeKD-M13 for the optode varied from 470 to 625 nm with increasing degree of deprotonation.33 Binding constants and selectivity coefficients of the optode membrane toward Cs+ were calculated from the spectra obtained, as the spectrum in aqueous 1M NaOH solution was also taken following each measurement.

After soaking the optode membrane in 1mM aqueous CsCl solution, the color of this membrane changed significantly from yellow to green (Figure 2a). On the other hand, the film color remained unchanged in solutions with other cations (Na+, K+, Ca2+, Mg2+). UV/vis absorption spectra of the membrane clearly indicate disappearance of the band at 480 nm with new peaks emerging around 610 nm with increasing concentration of Cs+ (Figure 2b and Figure S1). A response curve drawn from the peak at 610 nm indicates that this optode membrane reacts to Cs+ over 100¯M (Figure 2c).

As shown in Table 1, the optode membrane showed excellent Cs+ selectivity, Kijopt against other cations: 200-fold against K+ and 10,000-fold against Na+. On the other hand, it shows poor selectivity for Rb+ (Kexch = 8.88 © 10¹6, ca. 6-fold). However, since Rb+ is a minor species in the environment, this would not usually present a problem for

practical measurements. These selectivity coefficients are reasonable based on the reported results using the ion-selectiveelectrode incorporating the calix[6]arene hexaester.3234
The excellent selectivity against Na+ and K+ is promising for measurements under environmental conditions in presence of interfering ions. Recently, ground- and sea-waters are often contaminated by cooling water leaking from nuclear reactors. Thus, we have applied the membrane for Cs+ detection under environmental conditions: domestic water supply and seawater. In domestic water supply, a response to Cs+ was observed at concentrations over 10¯M (Figure 3a). Moreover, the membrane responded to concentrations over 100¯M of Cs+ in seawater. It is likely that the slight lowering of sensitivity in seawater is caused by base dissociation indicated by its higher pH (³7.3) compared to the buffer solution (pH 7.0). This dissociation increased the responsiveness of the optode membrane to the interfering ions (Na+ and K+) so that the optode membrane responded to the ions in seawater, even though their concentrations (Na+: 380mM, K+: 8.7mM) were below their detection limits in the buffer solution (Table S1).
However, the optode membrane still demonstrated detection of submicromolar levels of Cs+ even in the environmental media. This result indicates that the optode membrane is potentially useful for Cs+ detection under practical conditions, e.g., environmental water, contaminated water used for cooling reactors of nuclear power plants, serum blood, and so on.
3.2 Development of Nano-Optode Sensor for Detection of Cesium Ions. We have attempted to miniaturize our Cs+responsive membrane in nanoparticulate form in order to apply this detection system for microscopic visualization in order to achieve imaging in biological systems. By sonication of the membrane in Bis-tris buffer solution (pH 6.0), a clear
yellow dispersion liquid of optode particles could be obtained. Dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements indicate that hydrodynamic diameters of these nano-optode particles lie mostly in the range 100120 nm consisting of aggregated primary particles of 2030 nm (Figure 4a). SEM imaging (performed in vacuum) revealed that the spherical optode particles are lower in diameter than the 100 nm indicated by DLS measurements which is caused by swelling in water for the DLS samples (Figure 4b).
3.3 Characterization of the Nano-Optode (UV/vis, Response Curve). Sensing performance of the nano-optode dispersion was characterized. In order to apply the system for biological imaging, pH of the medium was adjusted to 6.0. With increasing Cs+ concentration, the color of the nanooptode varied from yellow to green, consistent with the color variation of the membrane form (Figure 5a). Moreover, UV/ vis absorption spectra of the nano-dispersion revealed an emerging peak at 610 nm with concurrent attenuation of the peak at 480 nm with increasing Cs+ content (Figure 5b). A response curve derived from these spectra indicates that the nano-optode also responds to sub-micromolar levels of Cs+ (Figure 4c). Curve fitting gives an equilibrium constant, Kexch of 3.09 © 10¹5. Thus, miniaturization of the optode membrane does not compromise the performance of the optode system. Therefore, this nano-optode system is also potentially applicable for in vivo Cs+ visualization in biological systems.

4. Conclusion
We have developed an optode membrane with high selectivity toward cesium ions under typical environmental conditions such as in domestic water supplies or seawater. The optode membrane is especially suitable for detecting cesium ions and also improves the possibilities of their detection at the naked eye level in environmental water samples. Nano-optode particles with a diameter of ca. 100 nm were successfully prepared by sonication of the optode membrane. The nano-optode showed an excellent response for submicromolar levels of cesium ions. The nano-optode combined with an optical fiber probe could offer high sensitivities and resolutions greater than micrometer level.27,28 Fiber probes ought also to be useful for the detection and visualization of the location of cesium ions in remote locations including under high levels of radioactivity such as those prevailing at high level nuclear waste storage facilities or at nuclear power plants.41 The optode is also potentially applicable to biological systems so that diffusion processes and accumulation behavior of cesium ions in the environment can be studied.
